ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .

The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

Otherwise she and the other TAs were fairly accessible but did not necessarily offer help with assignments as well as they could have.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Jon Terrence Powell  Jon Powell was an excellent guide for our term project. He was knowledgeable, accessible, and clear with instructions. Jon was an excellent teaching fellow.
Instructor: Jon Terrence Powell  Jon was wonderful! He was very accessible, and provided constructive feedback on our project. I have no complaints about Jon!

Instructor: Jon Terrence Powell  I felt that he was knowledgeable about the subject matter. His understanding helped frame my group final project and give our topic the depth it needed. I don't really think he displayed any major weaknesses and some of the times the course was weak was because of the overall subject matter. I think Jon, and the teaching fellows in general, could possibly have worked with the professors to give the course more depth. At times, I felt that the topics we discussed in class were very surface-level and lacked insight. I didn't feel that way at first, but then towards the end of the semester I felt as if we were continually talking about the same thing.
Instructor: Jon Terrence Powell  Jon was very kind and diligent at the moment of solving doubts and handling with the logistics of the course.

Instructor: Jon Terrence Powell  I am really interested in Jon's work on waste and landfills in the U.S. and worked on a waste related topic for my final project, however I don't feel I got to take advantage of his expertise either on the project or in class. It would have been nice to have a session with him, as we did with Tamar. I also felt he was often too busy/distracted to give us meaningful feedback on our project. We also lost his comments once because he only sent them on to one group member who did not see them in his email until much later.
Instructor: Jon Terrence Powell  I thought Tamara was a bit slow on grading, but other than that, the TA's were stellar!
Instructor: Jon Terrence Powell  TAs were very responsive, all feedback was great.
Instructor: Jon Terrence Powell  Jon was very responsive to emails and questions and responded to them within the shortest time. He was extremely approachable and friendly.
Instructor: Jon Terrence Powell  Strength - Always available at every class and responds to mails promptly Weakness- Directions weren't clear
Instructor: Jon Terrence Powell  He was always very helpful and approachable but we understand that sometimes it was difficult to meet with him because he had a busy schedule.
Instructor: Sarah O'Toole Bolthrunis  Sarah was really helpful overall. I think the NPV workshop was great and could probably be expanded/refined for next year.
Instructor: Sarah O'Toole Bolthrunis  Sarah was very accessible, and helpful with any and all student questions.

Instructor: Sarah O'Toole Bolthrunis  She's good at explaining concepts and was helpful during the midterm review, as much as that "review session" lended itself to being. As a grader, she was the toughest but offered great insight and comments.

Instructor: Sarah O'Toole Bolthrunis  Students are not allowed to use laptop or tablets, but TAs are, and often are working on something, with a constant "tapping" on keyboard, which is a large distraction to a class in that format. The fact that we always had the 3 TAs in all the classes in a room that we often run out of seats was not a good strategy.
Instructor: Sarah O'Toole Bolthrunis  Both Sarah and Jon were very responsive to questions via email.
Instructor: Sarah O'Toole Bolthrunis  Sarah is very intelligent and knowledgeable and was always helpful when asked questions or for help on an assignment.

Instructor: Sarah O'Toole Bolthrunis  Sarah was very organized and helpful. She was extremely responsive and willing to help, however she could often be slightly obtrusive and rude and was not always approachable.
Instructor: Tamar Makov  Interested in topic, good knowledge of it and very helpful. However, had very strong opinions and often did not like when students contradicted this.
Instructor: Tamar Makov  Very smart, accurate, honest and polite.
Instructor: Tamar Makov  Very strict grader Not sure her personality is apt for a teaching assistant role. Disinterested attitude
Instructor: Tamar Makov  Teaching assistant could be more open to students' ideas and opinions rather than adhering to her own.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: The survey nature of this course made it less substantive than I had expected. As a non-MBA student, I was hoping for this course to be an introduction to some applied business skills. While it did introduce many concepts and helped teach the language of business, I feel it was taught at a very high, broad strokes level that left me with strategic thinking skills but not so many hard skills. Breaking up into groups for all of the projects meant that the financial analyses were always done by the MBA students, because many of us didn't know how to do them. I think this was a great class, and understand the cross-listed nature of it, but I wish there was non-cross-listed class that could be a true intro to business course for FES students.

Generally, I tend to be more of an introvert--- or somewhere in between introvert and extrovert. That said, it'd be great if there are ways to facilitate involvement from more people in class. One way that I've seen this done effectively is to provide key discussion questions in the syllabus (or otherwise in advance) for each of the class sessions and/or readings. This takes a little more in-depth planning, but I think it could be a way to encourage everyone to be engaged in the conversation, instead just a few key people that are more comfortable thinking/speaking when less prepared. Generally, I really like the format and set-up of our classroom this year. It was designed to be engaging and conversational. I wouldn't change this aspect. Instead, I would give students a little more to prepare and think critically about before each class session.

I really liked the course during the first two-thirds of the semester, and then it got a bit redundant. It seemed as if the professors stopped caring about the class toward the end of the semester. One of the teaching fellows taught a couple courses and, although she was clearly knowledgeable about the subject matter, it was evident that she was not accustomed to lecturing and her lectures were not up to the standard I would expect at a Yale graduate program. Similarly, we had a couple other guest speakers who varied in ability to engage the class. One from The Nature Conservancy was quite good, but the other woman we had lecture (Diana Glassman) was clearly not used to speaking in front of students. A lot of her comments were combative and offensive, and she was not at all encouraging or engaging. I am sure she is very accomplished, but it felt as if she was talking down to us.

i wish this class gave more case studies and examples! both professors have consulted on many projects yet ONLY discussed GE's Ecomagination! It was so frustrating, repetitive, and even futile half way through the semester. This class could have been more "strategy" oriented rather than just general management concepts.
The case studies were relevant and helpful exercises, but a lot of the readings were duplicative and outdated.

Q 6: I thought the overall content of the class was very good. I wondered sometimes about how up to date some of the examples are, it might be something to consider changing cases and PPT content from year to year.

As an international student, it wasn't clear to me that I had to write a lot for the midterm exam so I recommend helping next international students giving them a clear description of what is expected of them.
The material covered was very superficial and it would be more suitable for an undergraduate class.
Dan lectures were great. Marian lectures were great too, but she had too many slides for every lecture.
I liked the course very much and it was very useful for the topics that I wanted to learn.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Excellent breadth of these topics. As an FES student, I would appreciate a little more insight into business decision making.
Professor Esty's lectures, the field trip
The case studies that we were assigned were very interesting. I enjoyed the field trip as well as the final project.

The debates were very challenging, but I think we all learned so much from them. It was also a good opportunity for us to practice public speaking. I also really appreciated the powerpoint slides being posted to Classes v2. I definitely referred to them during my studying for the midterm, as well as while I was working on the final term project. That said, I also get that Prof Esty didn't do slides, which was OK. It would've been good to emphasize that his "slides" were really drawn from specific chapters of his books. I referred to Green to Gold for more in-depth materials and readings on Prof Esty's lectures.

It was clear that both Professors Esty and Chertow were very knowledgeable about the subject matter. I enjoyed the readings and the class discussion. Dan Esty especially was a very engaging speakers and his lectures during the first two thirds of the semester were interesting, and I always looked forward to the class. I think both professors brought up very relevant and important topics that were a good source of discussion. The discussion in class was one of the best aspects of the course and I think it brought value to the overall learning of the subject matter. I also thought that the three assignments we had to complete were very interesting and helped me grasp the concepts of the course materials.
Great professors. I like that it was co-taught since students were introduced to different perspectives.
The material is what I'm interested in so I enjoyed going to these classes and doing the interesting readings.
That we were exposed to a large number of practices and techniques.
The cases, debates, and class discussion were the best aspects of the course. I enjoyed having the perspectives of both professors (Esty and Chertow), and they complement each other well.
This is really the only class available of this type, so enjoyed the material.

The class is very interesting because it offers students different ways of learning. The format of the class, the debates and the open discussion were key factors for students to have more proactive interventions.
I really enjoyed having both Marian and Dan to offer varying perspectives.
The variety of learning opportunities: lecture, reading, case studies, field trips, debates
Great content and interesting case studies.
The pace and that the teachers are smart.
The lecture in the early part of the course was great. Enjoyed the topics and class discussion. Class project was also enjoyable. The midterm format was perfect
The relevance and timeliness of the course content and class discussions. The practical examples from Esty's playbook added to the courses' relevance.
Real life examples
It was a theoretical but also a practical class where we could apply the knowledge that we learned and I liked that we used real case examples.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The exercises should have been uploaded to the class server earlier--we often had to request for the assignments to be uploaded, which I find ridiculous. The TFs also took a long time to grade assignments and so I could not incorporate their comments by my next exercise.
I would have appreciated going deeper into certain topics rather than quickly touching on many. For instance, supply chain is very interesting to me but we did not speak in detail about it.

It would've been helpful to have a little more clarity/guidance on the final project earlier in the semester. In fact, if we could've teamed up sooner and perhaps had more check-in's over the course of the semester (rather than just 1-2), it'd be even better.

My one major criticism of the course was that we discussed similar US-based concepts almost every class. I think the course would have been greatly enhanced if it had a more international focus. Since the student body f the class was very international, it did not make sense to me that we mostly discussed US companies, policies, points of view, etc. I thought that the professors presented materials from a very one-sided, linear perspective that did not take into account the overarching global world view.

I thought Marian's lectures had a lot of great and interesting material, but she often rushed through them and sometimes I missed the point she was trying to make because she had rushed through them. The lectures could be improved if she selected only a few of the topics in her initial slides and then elaborated more on those topics.

Marian's slides need to be shortened and be more focused. More real world examples need to be worked in like the case with Trane. Furthermore, our evaluations of our debates should be given to us immediately after class.
More case-study classes. Some of the concepts are to vague to be completely understood without a case.
Grading was pretty slow, so it was hard to get feedback after the cases or debates in time to adjust for the upcoming cases or final group project. Lectures based off of slides could be pretty slow.
The midterm was a little out of place for the style of the class, a take-home midterm might make more sense.

The course would highly benefit if it has a more balanced mix between teaching concepts and discussing about business cases related to environmental issues. In my view, these two ways of teaching can be mixed in order to have a better balance throughout the semester. Maybe instead of assigning that amount of readings, one case would be enough to introduce the concepts and learn how it is put into practice in the real world. On the other hand, I believe that the final project should have been introduced earlier in the semester for student to have more time to develop a good case. In addition, more attention from the faculty members on how are the projects going throughout the semestre would increase the level of the final projects. Also related to the final projects, and acknowledging the effort from the teaching assistants to assign students to the projects they most wanted, I consider necessary to have balanced groups between domestic and international students.
Communication around requirements and clear and consistent expectations for project deliverables.
Coursework could be more challenging.
More case examples and real world tools like marketing.
This was my favorite class of the semester, however, the last few classes were somewhat vague.
I thought the format was great. No need for improvement.

While the course was interesting, I found that there was heavy focus on profit gains as the central criterion in assessing corporate sustainability. While the sustainability concept itself is largely grounded in eco-centrism, I felt that the course structure viewed the environment as a fringe consideration in making a case for sustainability in a corporate environment.
Trying to incorporate examples from developing countries as well
Less work for the sake of work (midterm could be designed to be more purposeful and specific in helping us review the material
Some class material was a bit repetitive, some topics or new case studies could be added to analyze them in class.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: N/A

It would have been helpful for me to connect the debates, assignments, and final projects a bit more to the lectures. I think that it would have been helpful to have some class discussion after the student debates, or some class discussion before, to set up and frame the topic. This would have helped with clarity. Sometimes the debates started and is was near the end before we really knew what the debaters were talking about (I did all of the readings before class and still was sometimes uncertain what arguments were being presented).
N/A
Most people didn't read and still commented on class.
Very effective.
Somewhat effective. Would have been useful t have a few more discussion sessions than those offered.
The relationship was very effective and it was very useful to understand the material much better.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I am interested in a career in corporate energy finance and I feel that both professors are very knowledgeable in this field. I have a background in international relations and environmental science, and took this course because I wanted to expand my knowledge of the management and financial aspects of international corporate strategy. I feel that this course helped frame my understanding of corporate environmental issues.
The course nicely tied in financial concepts, environmental concepts, and general concepts on how to convince people to pursue environmental initiatives.
I'm interested in corporate sustainability and this was a natural fit. I wished I had learned more as much of the topics were basic since I do lots of extracurricular reading in this area.

I think this is a good overview of the important aspects of corporate environmental management and strategy. I want to work on the NGO side vs. the private sector, but it was a beneficial course to take to understand some of the challenges surrounding environmental strategies in the corporate sector.
good intro to my study

This course is very interesting for people interested in the relationship between business and environment. I believe it offers you the opportunity to deal and discuss environmental issues that business are facing in order to competitive in the market and industry.
Very well, even if you are not into business, it helps understanding the role and trends.

This course and the instructors were part of the reason I decided to come to F&ES. I had been looking forward to taking the class, and was not disappointed. The professors were available and open to discussing the course, as well as other projects related to the material. Great experience!
My academic background is both science and art-based, with minimal prior exposure to corporate finance but the well-structured nature of the course was useful in navigating the course content.
Yes

I think this course is great for anyone interested in Environmental strategy. However, at the same time it covers topics in a very shallow manner with no in-depth analysis. While this class encourages you to think, it does not really teach you any skills or new concepts.

This course was very useful for me because it was related to my summer internship and I liked that I could understand better what I practiced during the summer and I will be able to apply the concepts in my professional life.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Fascinating, relevant topic, and a very well taught course
I felt this was an important topic for any MEM student.
I am interested in working in the private sector but do not have a business background. I was hoping to get introduced to the "business language" and skills that I can bring into the field.
I've heard amazing things about it--- and they all proved true! Thank you!
See previous question response.
I took this course to better understand what it means to be business-minded. I wanted to learn how to persuade companies to take on environmental stewardship.
This course matches my career interests and educational goals.
I would be a good fit to tailor my career.
to gain background in the area
Only class available on environmental management and strategy
I took this course because I am interested in the relationship between business and the environment.
I took this course because I am interested in business and the environment
Content area appealed to me
To fit a corporate sustainability professional role.
This course was perfectly aligned with my future career path. It was a great start, and I am glad to have taken the class in the first semester.
I had minimal exposure to corporate sustainability indices in my previous job and I therefore found this course very useful in building on this previous knowledge.
Requirement for Business and the environment clinic
I am highly interested in environmental strategy and hope to work in corporate environmental management someday.
Because I wanted to learn more about the topics of corporate sustainability.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: No
Mostly, but as I mentioned above, a deeper understanding and introduction to hard skills would have been desired.

In some ways, yes. But I feel that it lacked depth of big picture international issues. Almost all of our discussions were very focused on the US and I thought that the course would have been greatly enhanced with some international depth.
This class met my expectations for the most part. I wish I had been exposed to a bit more financial techniques and methods.
I learned less than I thought I would because I already knew much of the material. If we had studied specific cases I feel I would have gained more knowledge.
Partially. I was expecting a more hands-on/case-studies approach
yes
Yes. However, I would have liked more a case-based course.
Yes they did. I learnt a lot from it
More than met my expectations
Yes, for a basic course.
Yes, perfectly.
Yes. Very much so - especially the overview the different sustainability certification standards and how sustainability performance is measured.
Yes
No, with regard to the response in question 20.
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Advantages were that I had some awesome teammates and learned from them. Disadvantages were that my final project was such a struggle because I had a few teammates who would not pull their weight.

I learned a ton from my group and really enjoyed working from them. We all came with very unique backgrounds and contributed different skills and knowledge to the team. As I mentioned above, however, with group projects, the financial analyses always end up with the MBA student, and I did not have the opportunity to work through those exercises and really understand them.

For the smaller team projects, such as the debate, things went well. Otherwise, the term project that we did in groups was really tough. Different team members had varying levels of commitment, which made it difficult to really produce a good/solid deliverable in the end.

The group I worked in was given a complex topic to research. I was disappointed that not all of the group members were engaged and it seemed that there were varying levels of commitment within my group. One advantage was that different members of the group brought different types of thoughts and strength to the discussion of content. But, overall, I felt that the work load was put more on some group members than others.

Group work is always a good simulation of real-world working conditions, and a great way to apply concepts learned in the class in a hands-on manner. That said, some of the group projects in the course seemed less well-formulated and thought out than others. Ours lacked direction and a particularly clear deliverable.

Advantage: I loved the collaborative nature of it and how it simulated the types of projects that people do in real work environments. Disadvantage: Some individuals did not do their work, leaving others to take on most of the responsibility of completing the project.

Advantages include learning about other people's work and learning styles as well as leveraging their backgrounds to make the group better. Disadvantages include the increased time and effort it takes for projects to be undertaken because group work requires more input from people.
Advantages: getting to rank the projects that you want to work on Disadvantages: our group size (five) was bigger than some of the other groups, which made it hard to coordinate schedules.
did not like it when groups were chosen.
Not being able to choose what group you are in for the final project made for some difficult group dynamics.

One of the most interesting advantages of the group was that it was balanced between domestic and international students. I believe the mix of different backgrounds and cultures was appropriate to promote open and respectful discussions.
There should have been more consideration for mixing intentional and US students so no one person is overburdened as the native English speaker.
I thought the timing of the final project was great. I also thought having different partners for the debate and the final project was nice.
Team members were very intelligent and dedicated, but sometimes had different expectations for the level of commitment involved.
Cultural and academic differences. Age differences.

Time is always an issue when working in groups. I discovered that the intensity of the semester funneled into the final weeks because of multiple group projects. The advantage to the group project is that we could all be part of a larger project by dividing the work in to manageable parts. It allowed us to present a more complete story and report in a shorter time frame.
Group discussions helped shed light on the course content. Through the discussions, I was able to understand aspects of the course from different points of view.
Disadvantages- No team dynamics, no help from the teaching fellows to foster team dynamics
Advantage: Good practice for real world situations, which often involves group work. Disadvantages: group work.

I was very happy to work with my group work. Sometimes it can be hard to work in teams but for this class the team was very cooperative and I believe we could work fine and it was a good experience to be able to apply what we learned in class.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Expect a high-level survey course that is interesting and engaging
Take it!

I would encourage students to take this course if they were interested in US views on corporate environmental strategies. I think that both professors are very knowledgeable and Esty especially is an engaging speaker. This goes for all of the FES classes I have taken so far, but sometimes i felt that the professors were presenting their opinions as fact. Sometimes I felt that we failed to look at the opposing side of an opinion or concept.
Take the course if you don't have a background in CSR and are interested in learning more.

I think this is a valuable course to take to understand some of the challenges corporate leaders face and the strategies they can employ when integrating environmental decisions into their businesses.
Take it. Try to do the first three assignments and participate in the debate early in the semester.
I will advise them to take the class
Make sure you understand your debate question before you start researching
This class is pretty straight forward. No surprises.

I would definitely recommend this course for anyone interested in corporate sustainability. Prospective students should prioritize readings. Very helpful to complete all readings for a specific class before the class session as it makes it much simpler to participate in discussions.
Do all the readings, even if it is repetitive with what is discussed in the class!

I would recommend them to take this course if they want to learn more about corporate sustainability and they can also learn how it can be applied in a business setting as well as to understand different case studies to be able to apply their knowledge in a professional context.
